Rich,
I can see what you're thinking, but there is no sand left in the iron=
 after the sand-iron ore is processed.  Most Onin and many earlier Heianjo =
guards do have a "sandy" surface texture to the iron.  Some Kamakura-bori a=
nd Yagyu guards (Edo period, btw) do as well, although the appearance is a =
bit different.  I don't know what causes that surface texture.  Most Muroma=
chi period iron guards that are believed to be made from sand iron do not h=
ave that sandy texture. 

One modern Japanese swordsmith who makes ko-tosho=
 and ko-katchushi style tsuba on occasion told me that he uses tamahagane o=
r ordinary modern iron in his tsuba, and that while there is a difference i=
n the way that the iron "works" he doesn't see any outwardly visible differ=
ence in the final product.  I'm not clear on whether he used an orishigane-=
type process on the modern iron or just forged it as-is.

Edo period iron g=
uards tend to have a more homogeneous look to the iron than their "koto" co=
unterparts.  I don't know how much of this comes from the source of the ore=
, the way it was smelted or how it was subsequently forged.  I think that t=
here probably is some technical analogy with the appearance and technology =
of koto and shinto blades.

Some modern swordsmiths recycle old-tech iron h=
inges and nails into their work.  My guess is that old smiths probably also=
 recycled older iron, although maybe more for cost than aesthetic reasons. =
 It's far from clear what causes the unique differences of appearance of th=
e iron of the major Muromachi period tsuba groups.

Jim
